txt.en: Give Mizâdi in Urmâkh news of her husband's death.
Search three spots around Esh-kimâkhi for clues as to Eshtali's whereabouts
Search the Crypts of Esh-kimâkhi south of Urmâkh for signs of Mizâdi's missing husband, Eshtali. Mizâdi said he would be wearing crimson robes.
You search the disturbed ground here, but you find nothing
Continue searching Crypts of Esh-kimâkhi south of Urmâkh for signs of Mizâdi's missing husband, Eshtali. Mizâdi said he would be wearing crimson robes.
You have found Eshtali - he is dead
Examine the man to determine if he is Eshtali
Search around Esh-kimâkhi for clues as to Eshtali's whereabouts
Examine the man to determine if he is Eshtali.
You spot something - it looks like a man tossed in the dirt
Mizâdi has received word from her spies that her missing husband, Eshtali, has been sighted near the Crypts of Esh-kimâkhi. Make your way there and look for clues to his whereabouts.

'I have a personal matter with which I would ask your assistance, [placeholder].

'I have received word from my spies of a rumour that my husband, Eshtali, has recently been seen outside the Crypts of Esh-kimâkhi to the south of here. What he is doing there, I have no idea.

'The leader of the Barkhûshim, that accursed Okhíso, claimed to take him when he drove us all from Kûr Anzar. I thought my precious Eshtali long since dead. I know it is dangerous, [placeholder], but I feel a dagger of hope in my chest.

'You have accomplished much with me here. There is no one I trust more with this mission than you. Please, make your way to Esh-kimâkhi and look for him. You will know him by the crimson robes he always wears. And, [placeholder]? If you are to return with my husband, know that you will have given me a gift worth more to me than any victory in this war.'
Give Mizâdi in Urmâkh news of her husband's death

'Thank you for that news. I had feared this day would come. I had hoped you would return with fairer news, but I appreciate your candor.

'Hope is a cruel master, and one that has now abandoned me.

'When I was a girl, my sisters and I would make shapes, shadows on the wall. We would make funny animals: ducks, and rabbits, and chickens. Oh, and the stories we would tell! The adventures those rabbits and ducks had! Such stories. My sisters have since passed, taken each by disease or famine or war. Sometimes I still see those shadows though; dancing, laughing, playing. I can still hear their laughter.

'When my husband would come home, I would first see him by the shadow he cast on the wall by our home. So broad and powerful, that shadow was the harbinger of my precious Eshtali coming home to me. Just like my sisters, I sought comfort in that shadow, always steady, strangely solid.

'After he was taken, I am ashamed to say I forgot what his face looked like, once so familiar to me. All I can see now of him is that shadow on the wall, insubstantial like a wraith, endlessly dancing through my memories.'
